item.title: 01%20-%20Alexander%20vs%20Hitler
item.description: Dan compares the way the modern world sees Adolf Hitler with the way history views Alexander the Great and wonders if the two men weren’t more alike than different.

item.title: 02%20-%20Guns%20and%20Horses
item.description: The West is Mike Tyson and the East is Muhammad Ali in this episode as Dan mixes Art Bell with Hans Delbrück in this look at a possible reason for the military decline of the Near East.

item.title: 03%20-%20The%20Organization%20of%20Peace%20%281920-1946%20CE%29
item.description: The early 20th century League of Nations stood for peace, cooperation, disarmament and international understanding. What happened?

item.title: 04%20-%20Romancing%20the%20Tribes%20%2852%20BCE-1813%20CE%29
item.description: From Caesar to Tecumseh, from the Goths to the Zulus — Dan touches on several stories of tribes in contact with civilizations and how we romanticize the struggle.

item.title: 05%20-%20Meandering%20Through%20the%20Cold%20War%20%281950s-1960s%20CE%29
item.description: The Cold War gets a rambling treatment as Dan looks at nukes, spies, brinkmanship, and the like. All the excitement of a Bond movie, but with the possibility of total annihilation!

item.title: 06%20-%20Shield%20of%20the%20West%20%28559-479%20BCE%29
item.description: Dan discusses how the West was shaped by the Greco-Persian conflict, and explores what the outcome meant for the direction of Western civilization.

item.title: 07%20-%20X-History%20Files
item.description: This is Dan’s “grab bag” show — an experimental episode covering odd topics, strange ideas, and unique historical curiosities that don’t fit anywhere else.

item.title: 08%20-%20Scars%20of%20the%20Great%20War
item.description: Dan explores the psychological, societal, and cultural aftermath of World War I, arguing that its damage went far deeper than most wars before or since.

item.title: 09%20-%20Darkness%20Buries%20the%20Bronze%20Age%20%281620s-1200s%20BCE%29
item.description: What happens when civilizations collapse? Dan examines the mysterious and violent end of the Bronze Age — a tale of sea peoples, lost empires, and massive disruption.

item.title: 10%20-%20The%20What%20ifs%20of%201066%20%281066%20CE%29
item.description: Dan goes deep on one of history’s most pivotal years — 1066 — and speculates how everything might have changed had the battles gone another way.

item.title: 11%20-%20Thoughts%20on%20Churchill%20%281874-1965%20CE%29
item.description: Dan offers reflections on Winston Churchill's legacy — from wartime leadership to political philosophy — and grapples with the complexity of one of history’s towering figures.

item.title: 12%20-%20Steppe%20Stories
item.description: Nomadic tribes from the Eurasian Steppe — Scythians, Mongols, and others — take center stage as Dan explores their influence on settled civilizations and world history.

item.title: 13%20-%20Bubonic%20Nukes%20%281340-1353%20CE%29
item.description: Dan compares the Black Death with the idea of nuclear war, examining how both act as civilization-altering forces — one biological, one man-made.

item.title: 14%20-%20Macedonian%20Soap%20Opera%20%28323-309%20BCE%29
item.description: A tale of ambition, betrayal, and power grabs: Dan recounts the chaotic power struggles following the death of Alexander the Great.

item.title: 15%20-%20Desperate%20Times%20%281928-1929%20CE%29
item.description: As the world teeters on the edge of the Great Depression, Dan explores the societal moods, warning signs, and fragile optimism of a world about to change forever.

item.title: 16%20-%20Nazi%20Tidbits
item.description: Dan shares a series of unsettling, obscure, and strange stories related to Nazi Germany — showing just how bizarre and horrifying the regime could be beneath the surface.

item.title: 17%20-%20Judgment%20at%20Nineveh%20%28883-612%20BCE%29
item.description: The rise and brutal reign of the Assyrian Empire is explored, culminating in its spectacular fall — and the judgment of history on its legacy.

item.title: 18%20-%20A%20Fly%20on%20James%20Burkes%20Wall
item.description: Dan riffs on the ideas of science historian James Burke, connecting innovation, causality, and history in a wide-ranging, Burke-inspired journey.

item.title: 19%20-%20Apache%20Tears%20%281870s%20CE%29
item.description: A sobering look at the Apache Wars in the American Southwest, from the perspective of both the U.S. military and the indigenous resistance.

item.title: 20%20-%20History%20Under%20the%20Influence
item.description: What happens when drugs, alcohol, and other substances shape history? Dan explores how altered states of mind have influenced world leaders, soldiers, and entire civilizations.

item.title: 21%20-%20Punic%20Nightmares%20I%20%28288-218%20BCE%29
item.description: Dan begins his epic on the Punic Wars, focusing on the buildup to the legendary conflict between Rome and Carthage — a tale of rising powers, rivalry, and mistrust.

item.title: 22%20-%20Punic%20Nightmares%20II%20%28218-216%20BCE%29
item.description: Hannibal takes the stage. Dan covers one of history’s greatest military minds as he crosses the Alps and delivers crushing defeats to Rome at Trebia, Trasimene, and Cannae.

item.title: 23%20-%20Punic%20Nightmares%20III%20%28216-146%20BCE%29
item.description: Rome rebounds. Dan concludes the Punic trilogy with the Roman response to Hannibal and the brutal siege and destruction of Carthage — total war at its most unforgiving.

item.title: 24%20-%20Classical%20Hanson
item.description: Dan interviews Victor Davis Hanson, classicist and military historian, about the nature of war in the ancient world, hoplite warfare, and Western military traditions.

item.title: 25%20-%20Dyer%20Outlook
item.description: An interview episode featuring Gwynne Dyer, where Dan discusses war, geopolitics, nuclear threats, and how world events can spiral into conflict faster than we realize.

item.title: 26%20-%20Addicted%20to%20Bondage
item.description: Dan explores the history of slavery — its scale, ubiquity, and brutality across cultures — and asks how such a system endured for so long around the globe.

item.title: 27%20-%20Ghosts%20of%20the%20Ostfront%20I%20%281940-1941%20CE%29
item.description: The Eastern Front opens. Dan introduces the most savage theater of World War II as Nazi Germany launches Operation Barbarossa — with horrifying consequences.

item.title: 28%20-%20Ghosts%20of%20the%20Ostfront%20II%20%281941-1942%20CE%29
item.description: Dan dives deeper into the hellish reality of the Nazi-Soviet conflict, with staggering casualties, cruelty, and ideological warfare unmatched in modern history.

item.title: 29%20-%20Ghosts%20of%20the%20Ostfront%20III%20%281942-1943%20CE%29
item.description: The tide begins to turn. Dan examines pivotal battles like Stalingrad and the unimaginable human suffering of both armies and civilians caught in the maelstrom.

item.title: 30%20-%20Ghosts%20of%20the%20Ostfront%20IV%20%281943-1945%20CE%29
item.description: Dan concludes the series with the Soviet push westward, the fall of Berlin, and the haunting legacy left behind on the Eastern Front of WWII.

item.title: 31%20-%20Suffer%20the%20Children
item.description: Dan explores the history of child abuse, neglect, and suffering — not as isolated incidents, but as widespread, institutionalized, and often culturally accepted across time.

item.title: 32%20-%20Globalization%20Unto%20Death%20%281519-1522%20CE%29
item.description: The story of Magellan’s circumnavigation — and the unintended consequences of global contact, conquest, and cultural collision — told with sharp historical insight.

item.title: 33%20-%20Old%20School%20Toughness
item.description: What did it mean to be “tough” in the ancient world? Dan looks at resilience, endurance, and brutality across different cultures and times.

item.title: 34%20-%20Death%20Throes%20of%20the%20Republic%20I%20%28149-121%20BCE%29
item.description: The Roman Republic begins to unravel. Dan introduces the Gracchi brothers and sets the stage for decades of political upheaval and civil war.

item.title: 35%20-%20Death%20Throes%20of%20the%20Republic%20II%20%28121-100%20BCE%29
item.description: Marius, land reform, and the use of mob violence dominate this next phase of the Republic’s decay, as Rome’s internal tensions escalate.

item.title: 36%20-%20Death%20Throes%20of%20the%20Republic%20III%20%2891-86%20BCE%29
item.description: Dan covers the Social War and the rise of Sulla, as the Republic faces internal rebellion, class conflict, and the erosion of constitutional norms.

item.title: 37%20-%20Death%20Throes%20of%20the%20Republic%20IV%20%2886-78%20BCE%29
item.description: Sulla’s dictatorship and constitutional reforms take center stage. Dan explores how power corrupts and what Rome sacrificed in the name of order.

item.title: 38%20-%20Death%20Throes%20of%20the%20Republic%20V%20%2871-62%20BCE%29
item.description: Spartacus revolts, Pompey rises, and the Republic’s elite engage in an arms race of ambition — all while Rome teeters on the edge of collapse.

item.title: 39%20-%20Death%20Throes%20of%20the%20Republic%20VI%20%2862-44%20BCE%29
item.description: The finale. Caesar, Cicero, and the last gasp of the Republic — Dan takes us to the Ides of March and the dawn of empire.

item.title: 40%20-%20Radical%20Thoughts%20%281950s%20CE%29
item.description: A look into the Cold War intellectual climate, where new ideas — political, social, and scientific — challenged the foundations of society and policy.

item.title: 41%20-%20Thors%20Angels%20I%20%28400s-800s%20CE%29
item.description: Dan explores the chaotic post-Roman world in Europe — where so-called “barbarian” tribes laid the foundations for what would become modern European nations.

item.title: 42%20-%20Logical%20Insanity%20I%20%281945%20CE%29
item.description: The dawn of the nuclear age. Dan reflects on the development, use, and ethical implications of atomic weapons — and how “logic” nearly doomed us.

item.title: 43%20-%20Wrath%20of%20the%20Khans%20I%20%281162-1211%20CE%29
item.description: Genghis Khan emerges. Dan begins an epic series chronicling the rise of the Mongol Empire — the most feared and successful land empire in history.

item.title: 44%20-%20Wrath%20of%20the%20Khans%20II%20%281215-1221%20CE%29
item.description: The Mongol war machine rolls on. Cities fall, cultures crumble, and the world gets a taste of Mongol warfare at its peak.

item.title: 45%20-%20Wrath%20of%20the%20Khans%20III%20%281221-1227%20CE%29
item.description: Dan covers Genghis Khan’s final campaigns and the sheer brutality of his conquests, raising the question: was he a military genius or a destroyer of worlds?

item.title: 46%20-%20Wrath%20of%20the%20Khans%20IV%20%281227-1242%20CE%29
item.description: After Genghis Khan’s death, his successors expand the Mongol Empire even further — with devastating effectiveness and unmatched brutality.

item.title: 47%20-%20Wrath%20of%20the%20Khans%20V%20%281242-1294%20CE%29
item.description: Dan concludes the series with the peak of Mongol dominance and the long-term effects their conquests had on the civilizations they shattered and shaped.

item.title: 48%20-%20Prophets%20of%20Doom%20%281530-1536%20CE%29
item.description: The Münster Rebellion: a chilling, violent episode in Reformation history. Dan tells the story of religious extremism, fanaticism, and an apocalyptic cult that took over a city.

item.title: 49%20-%20American%20Peril%20%281897-1898%20CE%29
item.description: Dan revisits the Spanish-American War — a moment that marked the U.S. stepping onto the world stage with imperial ambitions and a taste for power projection.

item.title: 50%20-%20Blueprint%20for%20Armageddon%20I%20%281914%20CE%29
item.description: The Great War begins. Dan sets the stage for a global catastrophe, detailing the alliances, ambitions, and miscalculations that ignited World War I.

item.title: 51%20-%20Blueprint%20for%20Armageddon%20II%20%281914%20CE%29
item.description: The war explodes into action. Dan examines the chaos of the early battles, trench warfare, and the stunning human cost as optimism meets brutal reality.

item.title: 52%20-%20Blueprint%20for%20Armageddon%20III%20%281914-1915%20CE%29
item.description: The Western Front solidifies. Dan explores the horrors of attritional warfare, the use of poison gas, and the grinding futility that defined WWI’s second year.

item.title: 53%20-%20Blueprint%20for%20Armageddon%20IV%20%281915-1916%20CE%29
item.description: Verdun. The Somme. The bloodiest battles in human history take center stage as Dan recounts the staggering sacrifice and strategic madness of mid-war Europe.

item.title: 54%20-%20Blueprint%20for%20Armageddon%20V%20%281916-1917%20CE%29
item.description: The war expands. Dan covers the Eastern Front, U.S. neutrality, and the shifting strategies that make a bad war worse — on a global scale.

item.title: 55%20-%20Blueprint%20for%20Armageddon%20VI%20%281917-1918%20CE%29
item.description: The finale. Revolution in Russia, American entry, and final offensives mark the end of WWI — a conflict that shaped the 20th century like no other.

item.title: 56%20-%20Kings%20of%20Kings%20I%20%28559-530%20BCE%29
item.description: The Persian Empire rises. Dan begins the tale of Cyrus the Great and how the Achaemenids forged one of the most powerful empires the world had ever seen.

item.title: 57%20-%20Kings%20of%20Kings%20II%20%28530-490%20BCE%29
item.description: Expansion and resistance. Dan recounts how Persia grew under Cambyses and Darius, and how it began to collide with the fractious Greek world.

item.title: 58%20-%20Kings%20of%20Kings%20III%20%28486-323%20BCE%29
item.description: The fall. From Xerxes to Alexander, Dan narrates the Persian Empire’s decline and its clash with a new rising power: Macedon.

item.title: 59%20-%20The%20Destroyer%20of%20Worlds%20%281945-1962%20CE%29
item.description: Dan explores the nuclear arms race — from Hiroshima to the Cuban Missile Crisis — and the terrifying logic behind Cold War brinkmanship.

item.title: 60%20-%20The%20Celtic%20Holocaust
item.description: A deep dive into Julius Caesar’s Gallic Wars. Dan questions whether Roman civilization justified the brutality it unleashed on the Celtic tribes of Gaul.

item.title: 61%20-%20Painfotainment%20%2880-1757%20CE%29
item.description: Dan explores the long and gruesome history of public torture and executions — how societies used spectacle and cruelty as a form of control and entertainment.

item.title: 62%20-%20Supernova%20in%20the%20East%20I%20%281800s-1938%20CE%29
item.description: Japan rises. Dan begins an epic on the Japanese Empire, covering its modernization, militarization, and the cultural forces driving it toward war.

item.title: 63%20-%20Supernova%20in%20the%20East%20II%20%281938-1941%20CE%29
item.description: The stage is set for total war. Dan discusses Japan’s invasion of China, the Rape of Nanking, and the lead-up to Pearl Harbor.

item.title: 64%20-%20Supernova%20in%20the%20East%20III%20%281941-1942%20CE%29
item.description: Japan strikes. From Pearl Harbor to the fall of the Philippines, Dan explores the explosive early phase of the Pacific War.

item.title: 65%20-%20Supernova%20in%20the%20East%20IV
item.description: Dan covers the Midway turning point and the beginnings of Japan’s struggle to sustain its war effort, even as its military proves formidable.

item.title: 66%20-%20Supernova%20in%20the%20East%20V
item.description: As the U.S. war machine ramps up, Dan covers the brutal island-hopping campaigns, the firebombing of Japanese cities, and the terrifying scale of destruction.

item.title: 67%20-%20Supernova%20in%20the%20East%20VI
item.description: The endgame. Dan explores the use of atomic bombs, Japan’s surrender, and the deep cultural scars left by the war in the Pacific.

item.title: 68%20-%20Human%20Resources
item.description: Dan reflects on war through the lens of human cost — manpower, sacrifice, and the cold calculus that turns people into numbers on a battlefield.

item.title: 69%20-%20Twilight%20of%20the%20Aesir
item.description: A look at Norse mythology and culture, and how the Vikings viewed fate, glory, and the end of their gods — with parallels to how cultures face their own decline.

item.title: 70%20-%20Twilight%20of%20The%20Aesir%20II
item.description: Dan continues his Norse saga, diving deeper into the myths, realities, and legacy of the Viking world as Ragnarok looms.

item.title: 71%20-%20Mania%20for%20Subjugation
item.description: Dan dives into the psychology and history of conquest — what drives empires and leaders to dominate others, and what that reveals about human nature.

item.title: 72%20-%20Mania%20for%20Subjugation%20II
item.description: The sequel expands on humanity’s appetite for domination — from ancient imperialism to modern geopolitics — with chilling implications for the present and future.
